issue.title: Update OpenSSL integration
issue.body:
OpenSSL is adding the feature for [SHAKE to squeeze multiple times with different output sizes](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/pull/21511) which changes the [baseline in liboqs OpenSSL integration for SHA3](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/0dafd4f02c5a8fc000502ae51005a9962b671860/src/common/sha3/ossl_sha3.c#L147-L162).
This issue is to propose using the new OpenSSL API to help validate it.

comment.body: Should not have referenced the GitHub issue within the commits themselves; please ignore the commits above.

issue.title: Refactor OpenSSL Implementation of SHA3 SHAKE to use new Squeeze API
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Refactor OpenSSL Implementation of SHA3 SHAKE to use new `EVP_DigestSqueeze()` allowing for multiple calls to squeeze

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Resolves #1539

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

Please correct me if I'm wrong but it looks like `n_out` of `intrn_shake*_inc_ctx`s are used solely to keep track of the byte number of the input and are unnecessary with the new Squeeze API. The `test_sha3` test ran fine when I removed all instances of `n_out` so I'm curious if this is no longer necessary. 

If `n_out` is indeed unnecessary, then perhaps we can also remove the wrapper structs `intrn_shake128_inc_ctx` and `intrn_shake256_inc_ctx` and instead point `state->ctx` directly to an instance of `EVP_MD_CTX`.

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: May I ask you to put this changes under some #ifdef? OpenSSL 3.0/3.1 are still available and these branches don't have the Squeeze API

issue.title: Not able to get OQS-Chromium browser working - https://openquantumsafe.org/applications/tls.html#chromium
issue.body:
https://openquantumsafe.org/applications/tls.html#chromium
I am not able to use this Chromium browser testing any post Post-quantum servers like-  https://test.openquantumsafe.org:6028/.
Intially, I installed it on Ubuntu 20.04 but since this was not working then moved to Ubuntu 22.04, then also this is not working.

I really appreciate your attention in this matter.

comment.body:
> I am not able to use this Chromium browser

Please note that the [test server is operating `liboqs` v. 0.9.2](https://test.openquantumsafe.org/) while [Chromium only has been validated to operate on 0.8.0](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/tree/main/chromium), so definitely is not guaranteed to work. Please consider using [Epiphany](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-demos/tree/main/epiphany) for browser-based PQ tests.

Tagging @pi-314159 for further input.

issue.title: Refactor OpenSSL Implementation of SHA3 SHAKE to use new Squeeze API
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Refactor OpenSSL Implementation of SHA3 SHAKE to use new `EVP_DigestSqueeze()` allowing for multiple calls to squeeze

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->
Resolves #1539

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

Please correct me if I'm wrong but it looks like `n_out` of `intrn_shake*_inc_ctx`s are used solely to keep track of the byte number of the input and are unnecessary with the new Squeeze API. The `test_sha3` test ran fine when I removed all instances of `n_out` so I'm curious if this is no longer necessary. 

If `n_out` is indeed unnecessary, then perhaps we can also remove the wrapper structs `intrn_shake128_inc_ctx` and `intrn_shake256_inc_ctx` and instead point `state->ctx` directly to an instance of `EVP_MD_CTX`.

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

comment.body: According to man pages `EVP_DigestSqueeze()` function was added in OpenSSL 3.3.

comment.body: I've replicated the issue. It looks like it was introduced by 1bb9887e8a04d1c4ac308c87954127079ab23b6d; on the previous commit the cross-compilation succeeds.

issue.title: Update GitHub Actions workflows for stateful signatures
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Integrate stateful signatures into our CI workflows.

I took the approach of simply switching on LMS and XMSS for all of our GitHub Actions builds that support all algorithms and adding an additional run in select places to test the configuration in which keygen and sign are disabled.

It looks like the logic around enabling / disabling keygen/sign needs to be tweaked in the XMSS KAT testing function.

We still need to test these on MacOS, which will require updating CircleCI, but I thought it best to put this draft up here as is for now to unblock anyone who wants to work on the test failures.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body: Hi @SWilson4 , I can help fix the XMSS errors. I've been away for a while, can you let me know what is the changes that lead to XMSS kat errors?

issue.title: set(OQS_USE_PTHREADS OFF) on MinGW/Cygwin
issue.body:
Fixes #1693.
Looks like if cross-compiling from POSIX to Windows, the CMake detect pthreads as available on the host and sets OQS_USE_PTHREADS ON for compilation, which will not work on windows.

comment.body:
This seems to fix the pthread linking issue, but in turn another issue appears (at least for me, running in our Focal Docker container). Running

```bash
cmake -GNinja -DCMAKE_TOOLCHAIN_FILE=../.CMake/toolchain_windows-amd64.cmake -DOQS_DIST_BUILD=ON -DBUILD_SHARED_LIBS=ON .. && ninja
```
leads to further linking errors, this time seemingly to do with our internal API :(

However, this change _does_ make the build pass with `-DOQS_BUILD_ONLY_LIB=ON` set, so it certainly moves the ball down the field. I suggest that we merge this as-is. I can investigate the internal API linking issue (they're probably due to my work) and add the CI test in the PR to address that issue. How does that sound @baentsch?

issue.title: set(OQS_USE_PTHREADS OFF) on MinGW/Cygwin
issue.body:
Fixes #1693.
Looks like if cross-compiling from POSIX to Windows, the CMake detect pthreads as available on the host and sets OQS_USE_PTHREADS ON for compilation, which will not work on windows.

comment.body:
> @SWilson4 If the Focal container is [`ci-ubuntu-focal-x86_64`](https://hub.docker.com/layers/openquantumsafe/ci-ubuntu-focal-x86_64/latest/images/sha256-117591aca53789075d63ec5e45fe13052842c1010c6b4e66eacde062ba63a614?context=explore&tab=vulnerabilities), `gcc-mingw-w64` is not in the install command. Could that be the cause of a problem?

I don't think so; I'm using a container based on that one on my local machine, and I installed `gcc-mingw-w64` via `apt`.

issue.title: Update GitHub Actions workflows for stateful signatures
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->

Integrate stateful signatures into our CI workflows.

I took the approach of simply switching on LMS and XMSS for all of our GitHub Actions builds that support all algorithms and adding an additional run in select places to test the configuration in which keygen and sign are disabled.

It looks like the logic around enabling / disabling keygen/sign needs to be tweaked in the XMSS KAT testing function.

We still need to test these on MacOS, which will require updating CircleCI, but I thought it best to put this draft up here as is for now to unblock anyone who wants to work on the test failures.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)
* [ ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)

comment.body:
> Hi @SWilson4 , I can help fix the XMSS errors. I've been away for a while, can you let me know what is the changes that lead to XMSS kat errors?

It looks to me like it's just a matter of the remaining / total signatures not printing correctly when keygen / sign are disabled: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/blob/0a44a2583534f8b96992c791b0bedac0d51e4d67/tests/kat_sig_stfl.c#L327

issue.title: Improve CI for macOS on Apple Silicon
issue.body:
Due to poor CI support this is currently a Tier 3 system according to our PLATFORMS.md document, but it should be better.

https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/1605#discussion_r1414029843

comment.body:
> @dstebila @baentsch It looks it should now be feasible to use an M1 runner through GitHub actions: https://github.blog/changelog/2024-01-30-github-actions-introducing-the-new-m1-macos-runner-available-to-open-source.
> 
> Edit to add: The M1 runner outperforms the Intel runner in a (very) limited `oqs-provider` test run: https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/actions/runs/7846813573

It would be great to start using this and move away from our ad hoc solution involving one of our own machines.

comment.body:
> @baentsch @dstebila For your consideration: at a glance it looks to me like a lot of our CircleCI runs (most of the Linux and MacOS configs) could be ported over to GitHub Actions, and [we might get M1 Mac testing "for free" in the process](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/issues/1630#issuecomment-1936219108). Is there a reason to prefer keeping them on CircleCI? Since we have to revise the workflows anyway to enable stateful sigs, this seems like an opportunity to kill two birds with one stone: move as many as possible to GH and enable stateful sigs en route.

Go for it!  No reason to stick with CircleCI if we can get what we need from GitHub Actions.
